title: Willem de Waal
text:
Willem de Waal (born 17 February 1978 in <a href="Paarl">Paarl</a>, <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>) is a South African <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer who is currently playing for <a href="Benetton%20Rugby">Benetton Treviso</a> in the <a href="Pro14">Pro14</a> competition. He plays in the position of fly-half. Like <a href="Joost%20van%20der%20Westhuizen">Joost van der Westhuizen</a> at scrum-half, de Waal is unusually big for a fly-half.
Career.
De Waal played rugby for <a href="Stellenbosch%20University">Stellenbosch University</a> before making his provincial debut with the <a href="Leopards%20%28rugby%20team%29">Leopards</a> in 2002. He then moved to the <a href="Free%20State%20Cheetahs">Free State Cheetahs</a> in 2004 where he would experience his greatest success so far. In each of his four seasons at the club, the Cheetahs made it to the final of the <a href="Currie%20Cup">Currie Cup</a>, winning twice and sharing one.
De Waal has also played at <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a> level, making his debut with the <a href="Bulls%20%28rugby%29">Bulls</a> in 2004 before joining the <a href="Cats%20%28rugby%20club%29">Cats</a> in 2005. When the competition expanded to 14 teams in <a href="2006%20Super%2014%20season">2006</a>, the Cats split into two separate franchises – the <a href="Lions%20%28Super%20rugby%20franchise%29">Lions</a> and the <a href="Cheetahs%20%28rugby%20union%29">Cheetahs</a>, which de Waal joined.
On 24 July 2007, it was announced that de Waal signed a two-year deal with French <a href="Pro%20D2">Second Division</a> club <a href="RC%20Narbonne">RC Narbonne</a>. He returned to <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a> after one season and secured a spot in the 2009 <a href="Stormers">Stormers</a> squad, his fourth different super rugby team. He also played in the Currie Cup for <a href="Western%20Province%20%28rugby%20team%29">Western Province</a> that same season.
